I have to say I'm a little jealous I didn't get the traditional Cheese/Sandwich Nazi experience. 

I went Saturday afternoon around 3pm. They were sold out of the ciabatta bread :( but happily made us a sandwich with what ever else we wanted. We got the smoked pork loin sandwich, which was OK on a french baguette.

The highlight for me was sampling some of their awesome cheeses. My boyfriend are already planning our next picnic so we can go back and splurge.
author: rachel c.

description:
WARNING: If you don't want to read me write about lettuce for the next few sentences, skip this review.

Now that that's outta the way, let's talk about a little thing called lettuce. Say Cheese, many have written about your great sandwiches (get the Cajun chicken with Pepper Jack) but you have one little thing that helps your sandwiches stand out above the rest: shredded lettuce. Many a great sandwich has been ruined by tough lettuce veins, lettuce leaves that are bigger than the bread & lettuce so plentiful that all you taste is the lettuce on the sandwich.  But not yours Say Cheese.  You care enough to shred the lettuce into small pieces that add just the right texture to any sandwich, and for that Say Cheese, I say: Thank You!

Next time I will have to try some of the many cute packed goods  & cheeses at Say Cheese that are bound to make me part with some cash.
author: Natasha R.

description: I go there for the sandwiches....and they are delicious.  The roasted turkey and the prosciutto sandwiches are amazing.  They have a great selection of cheeses and the employees there are all very knowledgeable about their cheeses and wines.  I would give a 5 star rating except for one complaint.  I wish the employees would wash their hands after every transaction.  They'll make the sandwiches with their bare hands, wrap it up, take your money, give change, go to next customer and make sandwiches all without washing their hands with soap.  Yuck!  If only the sandwiches weren't so good.
author: Ellie C.

description:
The owners alone deserve five stars.  Perhaps I'm biased because one of them is also my landlord, but they are just lovely people.  
Also, since I guess its important, they have some of the best wine and cheese around.  Oh, and champagne.
author: Christine M.

description:
This is a dangerous place for people who love cheese. My boyfriend and I visited Say Cheese the other day and ended up coming home with all manner of delicious deli items, including marinated beans, white anchovies, pepper shooters, the best salami I've ever had, one of the best cheddars I've ever had, and some fantastic smelly cheese. Oh, and some olive oil and chocolate. And pates de fruits. Clearly the guy serving us had our number when we walked in the store. Luckily we were having a party, and it all got eaten.

The older gentleman who waited on us did have a slightly gruff manner, but definitely knew his stuff and was great about offering samples. I'd trust him to make food recommendations for me anytime.
author: Heather R.

description:
They do have a HUGE selection of what I like to call my pieces of heaven!  And, you can never go wrong with any of their deli sandwiches - prefer the Brie with tomatoes, or any aged cheese with tomatoes. Overall, the staff is friendly and let you sample as much cheese as you want before making a selection BUT there is this one man (bit older than the rest with graying hair) who can be like a cheese nazi of sorts. It's like he wants you in and out with as little conversation as possible - the less you smile the better! And, get ready to face his glare if you can't pronounce the name of a cheese all too well!! Maybe he was having an off day? Whatever it was it did not add up to a happy shopping experience. Otherwise, I adore this little gem and will go back. I know, two stars off might be a little harsh but they will be added if my next few stops are better ones.

UPDATE: Went back there again and service is so much better.  Our helper spent lots of time with us as we had several different cheese requests to pair with different items.
author: Abha K.

description: this is my new fav place. amazzzzing cheese selection. incredible knowledge and service. careful, considerate, a real customer service experience. I absolutely love this place. and the bottle of wine I got got just $13? incredible! definitely make this a stop or if your local.... frequent this little gem. cheese, charcuterie, wine and all the little fixins. so yum!
author: K E.

description: Thanks to the glorious Jean Wang for introducing me to the Sanwich Nazi, aka Papa Cheese.   "You'll know who he is.  He looks like a fisherman."  She prepped me for the first visit like a nervous relative sending the baby of the family on his first solo trip into the New York subway.  "Remember, " she said, "Don't be indecisive.  You have to know what you want before you get to the counter. "  We rehearsed my topping choices on the sidewalk.  "And turn your cell phone off."  I've snuck in a few times since without telling Jean.  Once you get the hang of it he's quite pleasant, but once when I asked for corned beef he ordered me out.
author: Gil S.

description:
Best place in the city to buy cheese. Yes, the sandwiches and accoutrements are fantastic as well, but the real gem here is the cheese. The staff REALLY knows its stuff, and Bob, the guy that looks like a fisherman, while gruff, is amazingly enthusiastic about cheese. He's kind of like the soup-nazi at first... he'll kind of do an eye-roll if you show gross ignorance about cheese, but once you get him started and show that you have a sincere desire to learn, he'll teach you everything he knows. 

If your idea of a "good cheese" is velveeta, don't insult the place with your presence... just keep walking by.
author: Hannah Q.

description:
Every neighborhood needs a shop like Say Cheese.  I adore this place.  Let me count the ways:
1.  Insane cheese selection.  Truly phenomenal.  
2.  Great selection of tasty wines--small but well chosen.
3.  INSANELY good sandwiches.  They border on great actually.  (I love the cajun chicken).  

There's nothing much more to say--it's a simple shop with a simple mission.  Give the people great cheese, great wine and great sandwiches and they will love you.   Giddy up.
author: Blake W.

description: Say Cheese is a charming neighborhood establishment.  It has been around longer than I have, and while keeping to its mom and pop roots, it has also kept up with the times as evidenced by its slick website and ever impressive selection of local gourmet foods and locally produced eggs from organic, free range chickens.  Intimidated by the depth of the cheese menu here (and lacking in sophisticated cheese knowledge), I did not visit Say Cheese for the longest time.  But cheese neophytes need not fret -- the sandwiches here are excellent and you can opine on the quality of sandwiches without being a cheese expert.  The sandwiches are surprisingly good, given that they seem like a side note unless you set foot in the store.  The sandwich recipes are tried and true; the bread tastes oven fresh and the balance of ingredients is perfect.  We had the calabrese salame (with roasted red pepper, provolone, dijon, EVOO & balsamic, salt & pepper, $8.50) and roasted chicken (sundried-tomato-garlic-pesto aioli, jack, fresh basil, $7.50).  I highly recommend their sandwiches.
author: Chris T.

description:
Dear fellow yelpers, have you ever actually worked any sort of retail service position?  Were you ever annoyed by an uninformed but yet highly opinionated customer?  How about one that clearly views you as some sort of servant instead of a peer and fellow human being?  How about that one-person log jam who you have never seen before who you are attempting to help while 4 regular customers are waiting behind them?  I don't know many people that have worked serving the public this way that have not been fuming at some jack-hole behind the pleasant smile that so many people seem to think they are entitled to because they are spending money somewhere.

Just imagine how satisfying it would be to be able to be a real person for once without risk of bring fired for it.  You can tell off that self-important prick just like you always wanted to!  Guess what, the customer is not always right, in fact they are frequently dead wrong.

Welcome to Say Cheese.  They are knowledgeable and opinionated, and will share that with you, and yes, sometimes they are blunt about it.  The only times I have seen them be rude is to people that seemed to deserve it.

Enough ranting, I go there 2-3 times a week for lunch, and their signature sandwiches are consistently great.  I have also had great experiences with their cheese and wine recommendations.  Leave your sense of entitlement at the door, treat them like real people and enjoy!
author: Zac K.

description:
Excellent  sandwiches & delisious cheeses sold by some burly Italian guys. I love it when foofy places like this are staffed by big fat guys named Tony. I like getting cheese from some regular dudes as opposed to some snotty , pretentious cheese snob. And they sell fresh pasta from the Pasta Shop. Try the goat cheese & arugula ravioli.

Also, also, also they sell wonderful upscale chocolates and vino and Acme bread. You can shop for your ultimate night of seduction here. Close the deal, folks!
author: Maria D.

description:
As one of the anchors of Cole Valley, this place is a true gem in our illustrious city. Kudos go to Roger, Bob and Paul for their outstanding effort to make this place so distinctive. Ask Bob to teach you about cheese and wine and you will walk out not only enlightened but quite pleased at the gourmet selections in your possession.

Tip: Get a bottle of Champagne and some Brillat-Savarin to go with it.
author: Jon W.

description: Not just great cheese but also great prosciutto and the best roast beef I've ever had.  Plus, the people who work there are very friendly and also generous with samples.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Say Cheese makes a good sandwich, but I've had more than one experience of the guy behind the counter being overly surly. That could say as much about the clientle as it does about the staff, but who am I to judge?

Great cheeses and a nice selection of salamis.
author: Jason R.

description:
When someone asks you to 'Say Cheese,' they are really asking you to smile. Say Cheese in the Cole Valley has brought a smile to my face time and again...

This small cheese, wine, and imported food shop offers many choices for the high-class gourmand, but the true highlight of this shop are the deli sandwiches made by a charmingly old-school staff.

Caprese sandwiches, prociutto sandwiches, pasta salads.... Everything is delicious and made to order. 

You can also find the elusive Red Cow Parmesan cheese here, an item that is both rare, delicious, and revered by Slow Foods as a unique, heritage food item. 

I'm smiling just thinking about a sandwich....
author: Ben R.

description:
Say cheese is off the hook! I used to live up the street from Say Cheese and went there every Friday to get educated about fantastic wines & cheeses. The staff is simply amazing, especially BOB !!! 
I have no idea why people complain - - I truly love him and I am soo thankful for all the things I have learned. I was introduced to such amazing wines there  that I am a real wine snob now. I am not kidding you can pick up anything from the shelves and be happily surprised.   I had my first bottle of Patz and Hall from there and I will never forget the bottle of Chasseur Bob suggested! I am still hunting to find that pinot again - but it's always sold out..  
Say cheese is a real gem! I wish I had store like that in my new neighborhood!
author: Monja M.

description:
ah... we can be sensitive because I want to feel good when I spend my money.  Specially on something as delectable as cheese and wine.  It is a business after all, and most thrive on customer service.   My dentist for sure over-charges me, but at least he does it with a smile. 

I too have a love-hate relationship with this store.  It is convenient for me and sandwiches are delish.   When I see the old guy with white hair and beard behind the counter, I opt to come back at a later time.  He does annoy me.  All other staff are friendly and indeed very accommodating.
author: bombo b.

description:
Food and an education, all provided with grace and aplomb!

I seriously love this place! (Maybe too much,  my scale groans.) The staff is extremely knowledgeable and friendly, the selection is fantastic, and they will spend loads of time with you making sure you leave happy. The sandwiches are the best in the city, but the cheese is the main event. Oh - and they have a nice wine selection to go with. Reverie Cafe, next door, is owned by the same family. Another neighborhood treasure.
author: Lisa F.

description: I went there again last week and the service was not lacking. In fact I think the people were nicer than the last time. I went with a group of 5, we were all asking questions, trying samples, etc. and they have definitely earned a regular customer now.
author: Brandon R.

description:
There really aren't that many specialty cheese shops in SF. This one is small but really good. I love the variety of cheeses they have. Especially the goat cheeses. 

A few years ago I got my dad a fun selection of goat cheeses and some of the stinkier cheeses as well (Stilton, Gorgonzola, Camembere). As smelly as most of those were they were really delicious on a simple water cracker.

I've never tried the sandwiches. Maybe the next time I ride the #43 bus...
author: Marz W.

description: I've gone here a couple of times now, and I really like the people that work here. They are really helpful and will let you taste the different cheeses and answer any questions you have. They also have good suggestions on different cheeses especially when you aren't sure what you want.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Thumbs down for no buffalo mozzarella.   TWICE.  Arrgh why do no places carry that here?

Also, be prepared for some very expensive, artisan cheeses.  When asking for help to sub out the mozzarella for the recipe I needed, I was not recommended a cheese under $25.  For a SMALL block of cheese, which would be for 1 meal.  That's fine, I'm sure it's high quality, but just pointing out be prepared to spend here.
author: Alex J.

description:
This will be the best $5 you ever spent on a sandwich.  If tomatoes are in season, go with the mozzarella, basil, tomato - fantastic.  They also do other nice vegetarian sandwiches, several kinds of turkey sandwiches.  

But you're in Northern California, not NYC or Chicago, so don't waste your time asking for a corned beef on rye.

Their cheese selection is huge and can seem intimidating amd the staff can be a little gruff sometimes, but they're actually very knowledgeable and nice if you go at them the right way.  

If you're having a dinner party and want to serve some interesting cheeses, BigMig suggests: Say Cheese to get beyond the bland slab cheese you find at Trader Joe's.  So go in there and tell them you want to buy a few cheeses for appetizers and they can introduce you to some cool stuff.  They have some nice aged goudas and cotswolds (my favorites) and loads of other great cheese. 

Wine selection is decent, too.
author: Jim M.

description:
Say Cheese has an old-world charm  that draws me back, even as I live on the other side of town.

Lets starts with knowledge. I am not sure who I work with, but he is wonderful. I think he might be the owner. No matter how busy it is, he does not rush me and he assists me in picking out unique cheeses for when I entertain. 

As to selection, he has a wonderful variety. They even have an impressive blue cheese, which I used to look down upon. I really enjoy soft cheese the most and they have never let me down. They also have a great selection of goat cheese, as well as sharper cheeses. On top of that, they have other unique items, like British black crackers (get these). and specialty pastas.

In regards to price, I find there prices to be less than Whole Foods and much less than the Cheese Store in the Ferry Building. Remember, you are getting quality. For what you get, there prices almost seem cheap. 

I like this store and I think it is worth traveling outside your neighborhood to go here. Parking can be a little tense in Cole Valley, so you might want to take the N. It is quick.
author: Christopher W.

description:
The food and wine speak for themselves... the sandwiches out of this world... but this evening the guy and gal working did not complain a lick when I walked in at ten minutes after closing, though I'm sure they were itching to get home after a long day.

I was planning to stop by earlier, and was bummed when I looked at the clock and it was 6:30 and I still had to commute back home. I popped by just in case, and was not less than ecstatic to see the door open (it was then closed behind me, so I don't recommend making this a habit ;)). This simple experience made my night.

Even let me sample the best truffle cheese I've ever had on my way out the door.

And don't stay open later - this gives me an excuse to leave work earlier.
author: Joe C.

description:
Things didn't start out well. 

First.

Guy taking my order asked me to repeat my condiment requests for my turkey and cranberry chutney sandwich. What was that? People don't usually get lettuce, tomato, pickles and a little mustard on this sandwich? I don't really care, and why are you telling me this?

Second.

Query of whether they take credit cards was met with a query as to whether I am local. Huh? What's with the questions on questions? Stars were slipping away.

Then.

Guy told me how Say Cheese is part of a group of businesses fighting Visa and their excess surcharges. OK, I can support that. Then he told me if I didn't have the cash, I could just pay next time. Oh. Well, now I feel kind of bad. I did have the cash, thanked him, and headed to me and my sandwich's ultimate destination: Dolores Park.

Finally.

Consumed a very good turkey with cranberry chutney sandwich, which always goes well in my book with lettuce, tomato, pickles and a little mustard.
author: Jason B.

description:
I work near Cole Valley so it's easy for me to pop in once a week or so for a sandwich.  I am a girl who loves her sandwiches, so they need to be good.  Say Cheese fits the bill, and then some.  Every specialty sandwich that I have tried has been great.  Makes it hard to decide what I want as I can't stay loyal to just one.

The cheese selection is dizzying.  I like that you can say "Hey, I've got this great barolo I'm going to open up this weekend, what kinds of cheese would go well with it?" and you get a nice little selection of 3 cheeses, some crackers, and another wine suggestion that pair perfectly.
author: darla s.

description:
It is places like this that make me proud to live in SF and take Muni to work everyday.
Nicest guys, all willing to teach with zero pretense. Happy to give you a taste of anything. You can come in dumb and be like..."my girl likes Havarti" and they educate AND pair. The up sell is gentle and welcoming. 
Steer clear of the Dried Strawberries...way too good too be that expensive.

Tips:
7 year aged White Cheddar from Quebec
If the home made Bolognese is available.....get it.
$1 spicy pepperoni stick is THE best bargain in the entire city
author: Ryan T.

description: Great sandwiches.  I get the prosciutto caprese every week.  Staff is friendly and very knowledgeable.  Great place to get some appetizers too.
author: Sambou M.

description:
I have mixed feelings on Say Cheese. I generally go there to purchase a sandwich which I eat at the Reveree Cafe which is owned by the same owner. Occasionally, I will purchase some of their cheeses as well.

Say Cheese makes a number of unique gourmet specialty sandwiches which come on a variety of fresh artisan breads, and are often accompanied by tasty spread such as pesto mayonnaise, sun dried tomato, or specialty mustard.  Although the portions of meat and the price don't necessarily make it the best value for a sandwich in the city, the uniqueness of their selection and the ability to eat the sandwich at the beautiful outdoor patio next door at Reveree make it a reasonable value.

So, why do I give it 3 stars you ask? I would give it 4 stars if it wasn't for the fact that I find the deli workers here to be incredibly smug and  rude. Not to sound pretentious, but I cant help to wonder why these deli workers making my sandwich feel that they are better and more sophisticated than me because they know how to pronounce a few cheese names.  God forbid if you walk in here and mispronounce ciabatta, aioli, or gruyere cheese.  Both myself and several of my friends have often felt insulted here due to this fact.

Other than that, the sandwich is tasty and the store does have a variety of specialty items that could still make it worth coming too.
author: James M.

description:
I always used to be a big fan of Leonard's 2001, but now this is the cheese shop to which I owe my loyalty.  The cheese selection here is extraordinary - there are few better anywhere...and I mean anywhere.  Knowledgeable staff can help you find that perfect goat, sheep, or cow cheese - soft, hard, or anything in between.  They also have a great complement of well-selected fine wines - just recently I found the exact same Pinot Noir that I had had the night before at Jardiniere...awesome.

But more than just a cheese shop, they also feature other gourmet items, from olive oils and crackers to sweets and meats - and they make some mean sandwiches.

If they would sell smaller pieces of cheese, I'd give 'em 5 stars, but my one little nit is that they'll only sell larger chunks - something which was also a problem with Leonard's.  If you're a true connoisseur de fromage, I highly recommend Say Cheese...but if you ever get up to Saint Helena, in Napa, stop by Dean and Deluca and you'll be be like a kid in a candy store!

UPDATE - 12/7/06

OK, they don't have it now, but pester Roger, the owner for this unbelievable cheese that they only get periodically.  They fly it in from Italy - a fresh mozzarella with white truffles inside.  Oh. My. God.

Now, after going to Say Cheese for months, I have to raise my rating to 5 stars.  Their wine selection, while small, is extraordinary and their cold cuts and accoutrements are first rate.  Damn, I'm glad I only live a block away!
author: Josh M.

description:
I must confess...I love Say Cheese...this little shop has turned me on to some great cheeses and whereas the old guy who works here can be grouchy I also find him a bit endearing

Grouchiness aside, he can also be extremely helpful...

case in point...panic stricken man strolls in with what is clearly a very long list of cheeses the wife has sent him to the store to purchase, he has no clue what he is doing, ENTER grouchy cheese guy, cheese guy finds all the cheeses, changes some crackers around (b/c clearly the wife had pared the crackers and cheeses incorrectly, the cheese guy said so!), and sends panic stricken guy on his way...looking a bit relieved....

this anecdote aside, cheese...a store full of cheese, glorious cheese...can't beat that!
author: Alisa S.

description:
This truly is the best fromagerie in the city.  Ok I know they don't actually make the cheese, but I'm trying to sound sophisticated, nom de dieu!  It has a definite European feel to it, and by that I mean two things.  

First, an amazing selection of fantastic artisan cheeses, butter, charcuterie, and wine, with the expertise to match.  

Second, and included with the above mentioned expertise, comes a complete abandonment of the whole "the customer is always right."  You will, in fact, quite often be wrong. 

I have gone in here a few times with an idea of what I'm going to make, how I'm going to make it, and with what wine I'm going to serve it, only to walk out half an hour later with a much different selection.  How many people is this for?  No, that would go better with a harder, Spanish cheese.  You'll want this butter for that sauce, etc.  Roll with it, they know what they're talking about.
author: James M.

description:
Awesome place. My friend lives down the street and we ate here before going to Outside Lands.

Cute cashier, which is a plus. 

Sandwich was great - roast chicken with sundried tomato on rye. Yum.

Also this is the first place I've found Vosges' Bacon chocolate bar on sale. Bought one and loved it.

Go here if you love sandwiches, meat, cheese, chocolate, or eye candy. ;)
author: Emily M.

description:
*** Updated 11/19/09 *** 

After all the work I've done to make it to Inner Sunset nabester-dom, I figure I'm allowed the indulgence of having at least one yuppie boutique-store that I can visit whenever I want.  And I choose Say Cheese.  Yes, I can get a better deal on cheese at Rainbow, but this place is just so darn bright, charming, and village-y.  Every time I come in I get sucked into a conversation over which cheese would be best (and they've always got my number--like recommending Gruyere for my flame-broiled breakfast scramble, brilliant!).  Of course I also get sucked into sampling stuff, and then buying more (or more lavishly) than I intended to.  But if you can rob me and still make me walk away feeling like a million bucks, well, my hat is off to you sir.

And on top of all that, you can also get a wide variety of gourmet sandwiches here--some of the freshest and most meticulous this side of Estela's.  And yes, you can have it with any cheese you want.
author: Wes M.

description: Selection of gourmet sandwiches, great cheese selection and other things to add for a picnic or night at someone's house.
author: around town e.

description:
Thank you for approaching me. You told me that I should go all out and just get a Burgundy. You recommended two and told me that these would be $150 in a restaurant and that you can't get them anywhere else in the city. You got me all excited at the prospect of a good bottle of wine.

But then the little voices in my head began to argue. $45-$55 for a bottle of wine? In the end I bought the less expensive of the two you showed me.  I am so GLAD! That is the best bottle of wine I have had in years. I had forgotten what a good wine tasted like. 

I tried a lesser Beaujolais the other day and it just wasn't the same. I'll definitely be back to try the other Burgundy and to ask for more recommendations. I hear you have lots of cheese, too...
author: Jessica W.

description:
Say Cheese is an amazing cheese shop seconds away from my house in Cole Valley. The selection of cheeses, Italian meats , wine and other high end ingredients are amazing. During the short season they even carry the very rare white truffles! But don't be fooled by all these expensive delicacies. If all you have is $5 or $6 then you have really come to the right place! They have an amazing selection of sandwiches, none of which are priced over $6. As a deli I don't think anyone else in the city can beat Say Cheese, especially for the price. The only down side is that they don't have a hot food license, which means nothing is cooked, toasted, or warmed in any way. 

If you love making your own antipasti dishes,  trying cheeses you've never even heard of, great sandwiches, and a small neighborhood feel, then this is a place to check out. There aren't enough of these little shops  in San Francisco. More than likely it will remind you a little of New York.
author: Ben H.

description: best sandwiches i've found in sf!  especially love that prosciutto caprese and tandoori chicken.  the staff is friendly and really knowledgeable about cheeses. a little neighborhood gem!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
Say Cheese is like the worst blow job of your life.

I'll elaborate: You're getting a blow job so you can't compain = You're getting really delicious ingredients so whatever you end up with is probably going to taste good.  However: There are teeth and braces heavily involved throughout the process = There's so much attitude with those ingredients that in retrospect you'll probably wish the whole thing never happened.

I've been into Say Cheese a few times.  The cheese is fresh, the wine selection is decent, if limited, there are lots of little odds and ends that taste delicious (albeit for a ransom).  That said, the service is so inevitably terrible Cheese's motto may as well be, "It's your pleasure to be served by us."

Thanks but no thanks.  I order a sharp Italian cheese, you give me fresh Mozarrela.  Alex?  What is: The wrong answer.  By a mile.

Buy local, buy mom and pop, blah blah blah...if mom and pop means enough attitude to fill a Whole Foods, well, I'll patronize the latter.

One star for the ingredients.
author: Matt E.

description:
Despite popular lore, the vast majority of the Say Cheese staff is perfectly friendly, quite helpful, and not particularly snobby. Of the four or five cheesemen I typically encounter at the store, only one of them is a total bonehead. His name begins and ends with a B and he likes to tell you just how smart he is, how fast he can ski (VERY fast), how many famous friends he has (none, but he'll bluff), etc etc. All these gifts of wisdom free -- just for walking in the door! Avoid this man at all costs. 

Everyone else (especially the fisherman guy) is cool. And they do have some excellent cheeses. The bargain basket can be fun -- hunt through for some $2 supplements to your otherwise expensive cheese tastes. Sandwiches are tasty though uncomplicated.

It's a great resource if you live in the 'hood, it is. HOWEVER, psssst, your better off hiking to Rainbow if you can. The selection is more extensive and without a dip in quality. Plus no one will brag about their fake masters degrees or skiing prowess.

But UNLIKE Rainbow, these guys boast a fine collection of charcuterie, which -- according to my boyfriend -- is really, really cool. They have two types of mortadella (I know most yelpers are looking for a place where they can actually choose their mortadella) and a bunch of salamis. Much to my surprise, I hugely enjoyed the little slices of salami I ate with my last Say Cheese picnic. So saaaaaaaltyyyyyyy.....
author: Beah B.

description:
Agreed, this place has a great selection of foods, cheeses, and some wine from around the world.  Not many other places like this in San Francisco.

Some of the guys that work here are awesome and provide great answers to questions and tons of interesting info.  I think the only deduction point I can see is that well, sometimes they can just be plain assholes.  I used to go there so often and they would rarely acknowledge me as a regular.(I don't want a discount or anything, just a friendly hello or something)

The guy who owns the place is real nice though.
author: Alexander T.

description:
Great place! I'm not a cheese expert, but the staff here can work with you to find something you like.

Spanish cheese and an exceptional brea cheese from France were my first selection. I plan to go here often. Oh yeah, now, its mandatory to hit the gym!
author: Sai M.

description:
Great cheeses.  Great meats.  Great wines.  Great sandwiches.
I love this place.
Whether you are throwing a soiree, or just want some good snacks to eat while watching the game, Say Cheese is your place.  Not only do they have everything you need, but the staff is very knowledgeable and can answer just about any questions you have and even help you put together the right menu and wines.

If you go on a crowded day, you will wait in line for a while, but it's worth it.  A word of warning:  If you do go on a crowded day, the owner can be a little like the Soup-Nazi.  He has no patience for loligaggers and lookyloos.  If he asks you what sandwich you want and you sit there with you mouth open mumbling "Uuuum...  I don't know... What about..."  he will move on to the next customer, and you may not get your sandwich.  But that's what the rest of us love about him.  If you don't know what you want, get the fuck out of my way!  I've got picnics to go to!
author: Salim C.

description: Very knowledgeable staff.  They are often busy but try to take the time to help each customer.  My 3 year-old son LOVES coming here and has developed quite an expensive cheddar cheese habit.  I love that they're always willing to let him try things.  Delicious cheeses.
author: Susan L.

description:
I literally had watched "What about Bob?" the day I went here for the first time.
Well, what about Bob? He was most helpful despite a potentially surly outward apperance.
I found his bluntness and passion for cheese to be most helpful in my daunting decision-making process. Mozarella? Salumi with fennel? 11 kinds of mouth-watering blue cheese? Gruyere? All of the above? OK.

The rest of the staff was equally knowledgeable. 
Everything I've ever tasted or purchased here has been exceptional.
I've never had such delicious blue cheese and now I'm addicted.
HELP.
Oh, and they cater. Yum!
author: Claire S.

description:
Great sandwhiches. Good cheese collection. (Sure it's expensive, but we're in CA, not France so cheese is just expensive here!)

I love that they're opinionated about cheese. I wouldn't trust anyone who wasn't so passionate about queso that they won't speak up about it. 

I wish they had more of the cheese I live -- the stuff that smells like socks stuffed in a locker and allowed to be fermented with anchovy sauce for about a decade. Now THAT'S cheese!
author: joann p.

description:
I will always remember Say Cheese for two reasons (one negative, one positive).

1. The first time I went there, I was hanging out with my friends on the sidewalk, eating our sandwiches (delicious). A really weird old man approached me, complimented me on my red hair, then proceeded to tell me he likes to photograph young redheaded men on his balcony and maybe I would like to come back to his place and... Meanwhile my buddies are watching this awkwardness ensue and not saying anything. Great friends. This exact same man pitched his photo shoot to me at the Folsom Street Fair back in 2005 (I was eating watermelon at the time). I mean, shouldn't friends intervene here? I guess it was flattering and all, but come on... Perhaps he is a world famous photographer, but he just came across as a creepy old man with a fetish for redheaded boys.

2. The second time I went there, my buddy Nick chatted with the main cheese man and scored us some uber-salty Greek cheese named Haloumi. Wow. It was the best cheese I have ever eaten in my life. We sliced it up and fried it a bit in a pan. You must eat this cheese!
author: Trey F.

description:
Oh man... the sandwiches!  The f-ing sandwiches!


*drool*
author: Matt O.

description:
Back when I lived in Cole Valley, I'd regularly get the tasty sandwiches here. They're still making them, and still selling a vast selection of cheeses. They also have a full deli selection, including imported French butter if you want to get your Julia Child on.

Even if you only like cheese on your pizza, it's still a great place to stock up for parties. The owner and staff knows about all things cheese, from the obscure to the ridiculous - ask the owner what type of cheese Sharon Stone preferred back when she was living in the City.
author: Timothy O.

description:
I heart Say Cheese! Yes, the two men who seem to be in the shop a lot aren't the most effusive people on the planet at first blush, but get them talking about food and it's a different story. They are so helpful. If they don't have what you're looking for, they'll help you find it somewhere else. Ask them to recommend a cheese and they want to make sure you like it before they sell it to you.
If you're just looking for "cheese," then yeah, I could see them being disinterested. But if you're looking for a certain type of cheese, then they're really great.
author: Little M.

description:
This place is the awesome sauce and then some.  The gormet sandwiches are to DIE for at only about $6 which makes them very affordable.  Plus, you know they're made with love.  Just watch the guys!  Some are better at the art of sandwich making than others but you'll get to know each of the employees over time and appreciate them.

Beyond that sandwiches, the cheese selection is amazing.  I buy cheese there quite often and devour it.  They're really good about helping you pick the right cheese for you too.   They also have pasta, brats, salami, wine...all worth checking out.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
Yeah.  Love the gourmet sandwiches from this shop and need I talk about the cheese here???

side note- I'm so so glad that I'm not lactose intolerant being that I'm asian.  So I didn't get the enzyme to break down alcohol properly, which my brother did and you should see him down half a bottle jack daniels, but I'm so glad I can do shots of milk and gobble loads of cave-aged whatever-cheeses and have ice cream for breakfast.
author: Julia H.

description:
I don't know why so many people are complaining about the service because I've always had quite pleasant conversations when I go there to buy my sandwiches.  They really take their time to make them just how you like it.  The sandwiches are generous and super yummy; great to pack for a hike or the beach or the park...

I like Say Cheese; even if I don't love cheese!
author: Mei B.

description: Stumbled upon this cute little neighborhood cheese and gourmet goods shop after brunching in the neighborhood.  Guys behind the counter were SUPER helpful and friendly.  Offered tastes of anything we asked about.  Got a wonderful mix of olives and a couple really good cheeses for a dinner party that evening.  Wish we had a place like this in Dogpatch!
author: Kevin M.

description: This is a smaller cheese shop, with fine cheeses and nice wine selection. A lot of locals go here, so since I'm from out of town I took that as a good sign. Didn't get the name of the gentleman that helped us, but we were able to take our time and sample several selections before nailing down a good French triple cream, awesome blue cheese and one of their local selections. The staff was very helpful, and they cut us just the amount we asked for. Some of the cheeses like their swiss and jack were boring and bland tasting, but the ones we took home were awesome. This shop is in a great neighborhood, with lots of cool eateries in the surrounding area.
author: Tara C.

description:
I've been to many a cheese shop in my life. This one is my favorite, hands down. It beats out the Cheeseboard in Oakland. It even beats every cheese shop in France and the rest of Europe (or, at least, the ones I've been to).

I've learned a great deal about cheese from that old bastard Bob over the years. He's a master of his field and truly a great resource for the neighborhood. 

However, Bob's brand of honesty is not for the faint of heart. If you're thin-skinned (sadly typical for many Yelp reviewers), then skip this place.
author: Tim W.

description: If you like freshly made sandwiches that have quality ingredients - get them here! They slice the meats when your order the sandwich. I love my black forest ham sliced thin. Before going to picnic in the park, stop by Say Cheese and get all the staples for the meal: cheeses, wine, bread, chocolate, drinks, jams and of course, the sandwiches.
author: Judy L.

description:
You gotta know your cheese....if you do ...they most likely got it
...I mean let's face it...we live in U.S...we have to have everything pasturized here...let's not complain too much...they luckily had some stuff pass through the border of bacteriology and sterility so at least one can taste the taste of real cheese and not that plastic immitation they sell in the super markets...yeegh. They got the stinky ripe stuff, good amount to choose from...they will scrape a peace to let you taste the good stuff if you are curious....
.....the staff? ....never done me wrong....maybe cause I don't do much small talk (it's not a cocktail bar)....I go I buy I leave.....Then there goes the high light of my breakfast....hmmmmmm.......good ol' Cambert.....
author: Alex W.

description:
What is wrong with all you sensitive morons.  Just because someone doesn't sugar coat every single sentence, that doesn't make him rude or snobby.  It is a deli run by an old guy not your f**kin yoga instructor.

Say Cheese is slightly on the expensive side, but so is everything in this city.  The ingredients are top notch, good selection, and they make killer sandwiches.
author: U S.

description:
Nice selection of cheese but prices are very expensive, they make you feel you are buying caviar or a delicacy like that.  

I know that prices of cheese have skyrocketed in the last few years in France along with other dairy products but Say Cheese is asking over $10 for a Camembert that actually costs less than 2 euros in France. 

Their selection of wine is ok, not great and also overpriced.

So overall it's nice to have such a store in Cole Valley but too bad they make their products unaffordable for most of people.
author: Laurent G.

description: Say Cheese influenced my decision to move to Cole Valley - it's that good. They have cheese you can't find elsewhere.  Go for the Prosciutto Sandwich on ciabiatta. It's amazing!
author: Katie M.

description: Great sandwiches. Originally from Brooklyn, I'm not easy to please, but I would definitely recommend the Smoked Salmon, capers and cream cheese sandwich from their menu.
author: Dick V.

description:
Everyone, and I mean EVERYone in the world should be so lucky as to live across the street from a place like Say Cheese (and probably also have a good gym habit).  For 5 years, I was that lucky lady who had daily access to cheeses from around the world, meats, olives, wines, the best sandwich on earth (fresh mozzarella, basil, and olive oil on foccacia), and more.  Bob and Michael... and everyone there are knowledgeable, funny, and wonderful neighbors.  They even put up with my crazy Dad and figured out a way to ship wine to him in Oklahoma.  
The Best.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
great neighborhood cheese shop with hit and miss sandwiches (some great some not so great- avoid the chipolte- sounds better than it is)
Top it off with a $5 truffle and cream soda
author: Staci J.

description:
Amazing selection, amazing sandwiches.  However...

I recently had a craving for cheese.  I wanted some mozzarella to have with dinner, so went down to Say Cheese and ordered two balls and a small piece of Asiago...$19 later I was a little upset.  I know cheese tends to be expensive, but I could have went out to dinner for that.

I recommend the shop, but be aware of the prices!
author: Lauren L.

description:
The cheese and wine selection itself would get about three stars.  They are ok... nothing spectacular.

I would leave things at that but the colossal arrogance and superciliousness of the staff here makes me want to give them a negative five.  

I went in looking for a specific cheese.  They didn't have it.  Fine, worse things have happened to people in cheese shops.  

The guy "helping" me took it upon himself to correct my pronunciation of this cheese.  I don't have a problem with people correcting me as long as they are genuinely knowledgeable about the subject in question, and that they have the courtesy to do it in a manner that isn't downright obnoxious.   In this specific case, both pronunciations were right.  Is this a big deal?  Not in itself, but it just set the tone for a really unpleasant purchase.  Had he not already cut a slice of cheese to sell to me, I wouldn't have bought anything at the store.

I then asked him if that particular cheese paired well with a certain wine.  He then turned to his co-worker whose attitude made the former's appear absolutely agreeable.  Monsignor is of the opinion that wine and cheese are not meant to go together under any circumstance and that wine and cheese fanatics know this.  Fair enough, my little dandy... I'm certainly not going to be purchasing any from your store.

I hope that the owner of this store reads these reviews.  My experience certainly doesn't seem to be out of the ordinary at this "purveyor of (a small selection of) fine cheeses".  Your store is ok, your staff needs an education.

I'm never going back.
author: Nihil P.

description: I am officially a fan of Say Cheese. Roger and his team did an absolutely stellar job of creating the perfect platters for a recent event I threw. I was truly blown away when I saw what they had put together for me ...and my guests thoroughly enjoyed all of it!  I was also so appreciative of how kind and patient they all were...these guys really care about their customers. Huge warm thanks to them for helping to make my event  a night of perfection.
author: Catherine W.

description: Decided to take the family to San Fran for the day. Headed to The Haight for a change of pace. After some hiking around town, we ran into this place. Fanstastic! They took their time and found a few cheeses that we liked - wife, me, and the kids. Handed out samples to make sure we enjoyed. Since we were still hiking around, they made us a package of bite sized pieced that we could snack on. Mmmmmmmmmmmm! On a side note, they were removing some beehive honeycomb from the beehive structure. Interesting for the whole family and of course we got to sample. Nice people, nice place.
author: Kirk K.

description:
I typically turn my nose up at shops who expect you to expect them to turn their noses up at you, the patron, because you don't know as much about the product they're selling as they do. I mean, isn't that why you own the business and I merely shop there? But once in a while a place comes along that is delightfully stuffy but has the merchandise and expertise to back all that prissy impatience up. 

Oh, Say Cheese, I love you and all your snobbery. I could seriously live on cheese and cheese alone and I've never ever tried a type I didn't like, so they already have that going for them. Aside from the vast and delicious array of cheese that is not only beautifully displayed but tantalizingly stocked in fridges behind the counter, these are my favorite things about the shop: 

- The turkey with cranberry chutney sandwich on sliced wheat. It comes with shredded lettuce, so um, sold. 
- The variety of deli staples - the tiny, red piquillo peppers, olives, and balsalmic-y cippolini onions are never missing from my dinner party cheese plates. And usually always stocked in my fridge for snacking. 
- The lightning speed with which they make my sandwich and the fact that it's always made perfectly, meaning I never have to disassemble it and reorganize things on the bread so each bite is well balanced in order to appease my food OCD like I typically do when I order a deli sandwich. 
- The bargain cheese bin - A little basket of the sliced off ends or leftover tiny bits of what was once a giant old round or slab. I love the idea behind it - that these snippets of cheese are just too precious to do away with and I seriously love the tiny price tag on what will become a perfect portion of late night snacking cheese in a variety I wouldn't want to pay full price to try for the first time.
- The curmudgeonly old owner. Yeah, sometimes I don't look him in the eye when I pick out a cheese, for fear he may snap at me for doing it wrong, but this also means that when he does approve, I leave there feeling like my old, cranky grandpa who hates everything and everybody just snuck me one of his prized werther's originals. 

The only negative thing I can muster writing about this beloved spot is that I never leave without spending at least $45. For basically mold. But even after a wallet raping and possible tongue lashing, I will always, willingly and happily, go back and throw down $14 for a square of cheese infused with bits of black truffle.
author: Sarah M.

description: I love this shop!!  Incredible array of cheeses, nice selection of wines, beautiful looking olives, peppers, and other antipasto, fantastic Spanish hams and other cured meats, incredible pate and foie gras, helpful staff, and one of the only places I've found to get duck fat for cooking at home!  If there were a 6th star available, Say Cheese would have gotten one from me!
author: Joshua B.

description: mellow yellow cheese...itty bitty cheese...sticky icky cheese...whole blue cheese...try dry cheese...may say cheese...taste shaving slivers...choose by 'bud...a small wedge trio...variety of cheeses....meat slicer selection...dry-aged salami....thin, fat, long and short meat stick round slicings...jar of salty fishy tasty anchovies....fresh bread grab....bag of chips making complete....rainy day home spread....meats, cheeses, anchovies and bread snacking....say cheese smallest densest packed cheese and various goodness packing shops.....
author: Hen A.

description: Came here on Valentine's Day to pick up some gourmet cheese for a little wining and dining later on that night. They have a lot to offer, it was almost overwhelming being that it was my first time at a cheese shop. We got a few varieties of cheese and some prosciutto, all of which were fantastic (except for one, i'll write that off as an "experience". Just wasn't my bag, but my boyfriend loved it). There is a little bit of pretentiousness in the air, but that was to be expected at a high-end cheese boutique. Their sandwiches appeared to be very popular and sounded great, but $10 is a bit out of my price range for such a simple food. In their defense, they sounded about as gourmet as you can get, so perhaps I'll shell out the cash for one sometime anyway.
author: Katie S.

description:
I never had an appreciation for fine cheese until I was an adult.  As a child I loved the sound of unwrapping the plastic Kraft singles, then I would smell it... smells clean ok!  I would share the cheese with my dog.  (What can I say he had a refined palate).  Then there was string cheese, when I started packing my own lunch at age 9, I always put in a string cheese.  I still keep string cheese in my fridge... ah the nostalgia of childhood.

Now that I'm a full blown adult (wink), I've acquired a taste for fine cheeses.  I still smell them, but now I believe the stinkier the better.  I find myself at Say Cheese quite often picking up a cheese for me to indulge in or a getting variety of cheeses for a gathering.  The guys that work behind the counter are passionate and knowledgeable about their cheese.  I usually go in and let them decide what I should get.

This place also makes sandwiches, which are good, but definitely are not the meant to be the main attraction.  I've had one bad experience here when ordering a sandwich, the old guy was awfully rude.  But I'm willing to forgive and forget.  (4 Stars as long as the sour old guy isn't around, otherwise 3 Stars)
author: Ashley Q.

description:
A Play in Two Acts
Act I, Scene i. 2002. My then boyfriend and I enter on a whim and are impressed by the wide array of exceptional cheese and compliments of fromage there are. The kind of stuff that feed Oenophiles words. My cell rings, I pick it up and start moving towards the door so if need to talk about my companion I could do so freely. Outside for a while, I try to catch his eye to give him an encouraging you deserve the sweet cream smile. He keeps his back to me the whole time. Scene ii. Boyfriend casually mentions, "Oh yeah, the man that looked like a fisherman (white beard) said that it was a good thing you walked out, because he was about to kick us both out for your phone." Of course, my man quickly said, "I don't know her."
Act II, Scene i. 2004. My best friend and I go to the crime scene to grab some sandwiches. While there I theorize, what's the point of knowing how to make souffle when probably the most favored man-snack was a sandwich? Why don't we ladies just learn how to make a perfect sandwich? The fisherman that nearly threw me out 2 years ago, heard my plight and taught Alice and I the cardinal rule of making a sandwich. Put the sharpest flavors at the bottom. Scene ii. Alice and I coordinating a speed sandwich dance on the beach by fisherman's wharf after reflecting on how an In and Out hamburger was not, the perfect sandwich. Perfect sandwich from bottom to top: bread, mustard, onions, pickles, meat cheese, tomato, lettuce, meat, mayo, bread.
author: Jean W.

description: The sandwiches are DELICIOUS. Not overpriced, and there is a great variety of flavors.
author: Barbara A.

description: Cheese! Cheese! There- I said it! I love a good cheese shop like I love a good rogering and believe me- Say Cheese gives good afterglow. They have a huge selection, delicious sandwiches and snacks, and knowledgeable, friendly staff who are passionate about cheese. On my last visit, I was sent home with some Stinking Bishop (oooooh, was it smelly!), truffled cheese from Italy, and a great recommendation for a new italian joint from my fellow countryman at the counter. Convenient if you're in the neighborhood or on the N Judah line. If you're driving, you'd better have a partner in crime who can dash in while you drive a few laps around the block because parking is a biatch.
author: Autumn K.

description: Killer cheeses and amazing sandwiches served up with some serious bad attitude from the old man who you know hates it when you go fast and even think about stepping on his lawn.  I walk in one day after work, fresh off the sardine can N-Judah, ready to buy some cheese and crackers.  The old man says to me "We're not making sandwiches."  I responded "Well, its a good thing I only want cheese and crackers."  What a A-hole.  I still go back not as much.
author: Chard M.

description:
best cheese shop in the city!
very friendly and knowledgeable staff. 
Roger has great recommendations!
author: courtney s.

description: I'm sure most people come here for cheese and wine but this place makes bomb sandwiches.
author: Sireenah M.

description: This place is amazing.. heh-heh. When my friends and I tried to get some St. Andre, the cheesemonger wisely told us of a better triple-creme cheese, as St. Andre had recently added too much salt to their recipe. LO AND BEHOLD, the 15 meter tide entered the Bay of Fundy. Now magic occured: a cheese better than St. Andre! Thank you kind cheesemonger. Lots of free samples, too!
author: O K.

description:
I walked in there today for lunch to grab a roasted eggplant/red pepper sandwich.  The guy who works there said "I don't have any eggplant." So I hesitated to choose another item for fear that they may not have it also.  He continued to suggest that I may be interested in the vegetarian offerings (I didn't really say anything, but was in quiet deliberation) and said that the most popular vegetarian sandwich was the fresh mozzarella with tomato and basil.  So I said, "alright, I'll have that."  He asked me to choose which bread I want, so I said, "i'll have it on multigrain."  He quickly snapped at me saying that my choice was a bad idea since he will drizzle olive oil on the sandwich and the multigrain bread would get soggy.  I had my eye on the panini... since he said "choose something with a hard crust".  I swear I said "panini", but he didn't hear me and suggested that I have my sandwich on a ciabatta roll.  At this point, I just conceded because everytime I am presented with what seemingly could be a CHOICE, he had already made the decision for me.  I was actually surprised when he asked me if I wanted a bag for my sandwich... since he was giving me, yet, another chance to make my own decision.  Finally I did, and said "naww".

I never left this place disappointed.  My first experience here was actually to use up the nifty gift certificate that my coworkers gave me for my birthday.  The fresh mozzarella with tomato and basil in ciabbata roll turned out to be one of my best lunches.  Their cheeses are freakin good (don't be afraid to ask for a taste... but be warned because you'll most likely want to buy the delectable cheeses so have some money for the trade).  They also carry Schmidt chocolates, wines (for cheese pairings), different deli items, chips, bottled drinks, coffees, etc.   In the words of Ariel, the Little Mermaid... "Look at this trove, treasures untold!"
author: Grace M.

description:
I absolutely love this place! They have an amazing assortment of imports from all over!

Their cheese selection is top notch and they are happy to give you samples before you plop down your hard earned cash. 

If you need imported meats and cheeses, and are in Cole Valley, this place shouldn't be missed. 

Today, I had a pretty funny experience though. There was a quite atractive young woman in the store and the young sales kid was totally into her. Unfortunately, you have a cantankerous bastard like me also there.. When I noticed that he had no desire to help me, I did my best to annoy him. I started asking about their sheeps milk cheese and the differences between it and the cows milk. Then I asked about the different meats and what are better choices for sandwiches vs antipasto plates. He got more and more annoyed with me as the minutes ticked.. Till I heard her say "well, I gotta go.." Which was my queue to pay and leave.. Poor guy!! :) 

bwahahaha..
author: Mark C.

description:
stopped by here last week after zazie and loved it! wish they had one in my hood!

very nice, friendly, educated staff!!
author: Art A.

description: Helpful and professional staff--you can say, "A friend invited me over for fresh crab he caught today--what wine and cheese should I bring?" (A mild goat cheese, FYI.)  And bang--you have an authoritative answer and happy hosts.
author: Gretchen T.

description: The counter server bagged on me for living in the Marina and I'm still giving the place five stars. Say Cheese stocks some of the most unique and hard-to-find artisinal cheeses I've ever seen, including the ever-elusive pecorino fresco that I've been hunting since my last trip to Italy. I'm also a sucker for places with well-edited wine selections (Bev Mo, I hate you, just for the record) that I know I'm unlikely to find anywhere else. Quite possibly the most deliciousness per square foot in the entire city.
author: Heather F.

description: I'll agree with other reviewers that the attitudes of the employees are kinda "fresh", but the sandwich I got was so yummy, it pretty much made up for it.  The guy helping me made my sandwich in under two minutes, literally, and it was great, I got the chicken sandwich with pesto mayo.  I do wish they would be friendlier about sampling, since I know nothing about cheese and I don't want to feel obligated to buy something if I don't know if I'm gonna like it.
author: Elle L.

description: Why did Seinfeld love the Soup Nazi? Was it because the food was so good? Was he a masochist? Was it really worth it? To answer these questions for yourself venture into Say Cheese. Everything there is to die for. The fromage, sandwiches, and other deli foods are from heaven, the help from the lowest depths of Hell. Make sure your requests are accurate and well researched, or pay the price of the eternal torture of your soul! Although you may burn in the sulfurous pit, you'll be eating the best sandwich you've ever had.
author: Ricky J.

description:
Ahh, Say Cheese. You, your sandwiches, and your delightfully unfriendly employees have earned a spot in my heart as a local favorite.
What everyone says about the guys that work here is true. They're not your average Red Robin employees, eagerly waiting to sing birthday songs and snap your photograph. But you know what? That's not what you go to a hole in the wall sandwich, meat and cheese shop for, is it? And after a while, once you've been in enough, you either forget the unpleasant atmosphere or the guys start to loosen up and actually talk to you (I like to think I fall into the latter position).
They have an amazing vegetarian sandwich selection compared to many places close by my hood, which automatically gets an A+ from me. And a belly-filling sandwich for $6 out the door? Sold.
The sandwiches are all amazing, they sell bacon-flavored chocolate (you know, if you're into that sort of thing), and have a good wine selection to boot. What's not to love?
My entire household eats here all too often and bring our friends in whenever they're around.
Hiiiiighly recommended. This should be a recommended stop on any picnic trip to the park.
author: Kristopher H.

description: One of the best specialty cheese shops in the city, if not the Bay Area. It's a veritable Who's Who in the world of international dairy. More common fare like Gouda sits side-by-side with flavors like pesto pine-nut brie. They also carry an eclectic selection of wines and an array of condiments, pastas, dried fruits, and nuts. A dangerous place for fromage lovers, who will be tempted to take home half the stock.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Can't stay away from the Humbolt Fog ANYWHERE.  Here the price is right -although most everything else is overpriced.  The fisherman guy is rude but the other guys are nice and really cute making every sandwhich and cheese just a tad bit tastier.
author: Kim N.

description: I know most people rave about this place but I've found them to be nothing but rude, rude, rude! They are snooty, curt and always gave obnoxious answers. I kept going back because I love their products but my last visit was the straw that broke the camels back. I don't care how great your selection is, I am a human being and deserve basic respect. This shop is right around the corner from me but I will never ever give them another penny of my money.
author: christine m.

description:
The cheese selection here RAWKS.  And the old cheese guy behind the counter really knows his stuff.  I walk in and am immediately intimidated by the cheese selection, as when I first walked into the Toronado.  So I take a breath and ask the cheese guy, "Do you have any Roaring Forties blue cheese?".  And he says "of course!  how much do you want?".  So I ask him to cut me a small wedge, and ask what other cheeses he might recommend to me.  I also tell him I love my Manchego, and what similar cheeses he might recommend to me.  He proceeds to let me and my friend taste about 6 different cheeses, all quite tasty, and all at reasonable prices (read: at least 30% less than ripoff shops like Oakville Grocery).  I end up buying 2 more.  And there were still LOTS more cheeses on the wall.
This is the 2nd best cheese shop I've been to in the bay, only losing to the venerable Cheeseboard.... ohhhh cheeseboard.  This place kicks ass.
author: Fong L.

description: It has been years since I moved from Cole Valley.  However, when I was there Say Cheese was a 3 time per week stand-bye.  I would go for their delicious sandwiches or when going to the beach have them put some cheese together for me. They have a triple cream Exploratore that is out of this world.  They guys are very knowledgeable about what they sell.  Don't be shy go in and explore their offerings and by do yourself a favor and order a sandwich.  They are yummy!
author: Scott P.

description: A friendly neighborhood shop always willing to assist the most remedial or experienced of cheese connoisseurs. They carry a wide variety, make killer specialty sandwiches, and have a great wine selection. You can often find wines reviewed in the Chronicle's wine section here. The owner and staff are always helpful and, thank god, normal. No attitude here. It can get quite busy, but its always worth the wait. Excellent large platters for catering.
author: J A.

description: One of my old neighborhood haunts in Cole Valley. Say Cheese is not only has a great selection of  cheese but happens to make some excellent sandwiches and sells wine & other sorts of european accoutrements, etc. Not the friendliest of help behind the counter but overall worth visting.
author: Deidre C.

description: One of my favorite places on the planet. Great selection of gourmet cheeses that you won't find at even Gourmet grocery stores. Ask them for recs - they've never done me wrong. Meat and cracker selection is excellent, too. I like to think of it as dinner, at least twice a week.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
This place makes me suspicious.  

I stopped in with a couple friends during  a walk through Cole Valley, the Haight, and the Lower Haight.  We noticed a wine with a posting from the shop that said it had received a 99 rating from Wine Spectator.  It was a 2005 Chateau Le Pape Pessac-Leognan (a Bordeaux) and was selling for $40. That is most definitely on the upper end of my wine buying range, but we'd never seen a 99 rating before, and the proprietor said it was a real steal.  Also, they only had one left.  We decided to grab it.  As I was standing in the check-out line -- and, by the way, I waited for 30 minutes on the single line that fills cheese orders, fills sandwich orders, AND rings up simple items, even though there seems to be more than one register -- the proprietor actually tried to hawk the wine to the guy in front of me, not realizing I had it in hand.  The guy ahead of me lamented that it had already been taken.  Apparently, this was an AMAZING wine.

When we got back home and did a little research, we found that not only did this wine get an 89 -- not a 99 -- rating, but I also find an online retailer selling it for $27!  We were quite disappointed.

When I took the wine back to return, first, all the guys behind the counter were like, "return...?"  as if they'd never heard of the concept.  They deferred to the apparent head guy, who asked me what my concern was.  I showed him the bottle and explained myself.  He said, "Oh, no...the 99 is just the vintage."  Hello??  I may be gullible, but I'm not THAT gullible.  It says 2005 on the bottle!!!  I pulled him over to the shelf of wines, where there were now several more of the same that I'd bought, and the same posted note.  I pointed out that it said "99 Wine Spectator."  He conceded that the sign might be "misleading" but that he didn't write it up.

Let's just hope that was a mistake.  The proof will be to see if they do change that sign....
author: Stacy R.

description: Staff is super knowledgeable and helpful. The Deli has a nice selection of meats and trimmings. Portions a big but the taste is BETTER!!!! My fav is the Garlic Roasted Turkey Breast...mmm..so good.  Worth the price, which isn't that expensive if you think about what you are getting.  A must go to!
author: Karlie N.

description:
Extremely knowledgeable and helpful staff.  A wonderful selection of cheese, meats, and gourmet products.  Delicious sandwiches.

What's not to like?

My recommendation, walk in with an idea of what you'd like to try and ask them to give you some advice.  you'll get samples and interesting insights into the wonderful world of cheese.

I've done this with anything from: I want to create a fun gift basket for a friend to what cheese do you have that goes with to, give me some cheese to match with foie gras, to give me something that'll last on a hike in yosemite.
author: Brett L.

description:
Horrible Sandwiches. Price gouging A**HOLE.

I ordered a ham and gruyere sandwich here that was probably the worst thing I ever had in my life.  The bread was stale and old. The worst part is I asked the man what type of bread would best. Of course he opined that this particular bread was the best because it was old and he needed to get rid of it.

The sandwich contained nothing but ham (a small portion compared to the bread), gruyere (very cheap quality), and about a pound of butter.

All that for only ~$8.00.


WHAT REALLY TICKS ME OFF about this place is the price gouging.  A keen shopping will notice that this jerk is trying to rob you blind.  

EXAMPLE:
Everything Flat Bread Crackers Package costs ~$2.50 at Adronicos (which isn't cheap mind you). This jerk sells the same thing, BUT instead of selling the whole packaged he divides it into four smaller packages using plastic sandwich baggies.

He then sells those small baggies at ~$3.58 each!!!!!!  He sells the same thing that you can get at Adronicos for ~$2.50 for ~$14.00. FOURTEEN MUTHERFREAING DOLLARS FOR SOMETHING THAT COST TWO AT ADRONICOS!!!!!! ABSURDITY!!!!!!!!!!
author: Carlos C.

description: Say Cheese is not just a great cheese shop but a fine place to pick up nice wine, great italian charcuterie and some of the best sandwiches in west SF. Make sure you ask plenty of questions and they will reward you with some amazing cheese.
author: Phil M.

description: Why are the old men that work at (or own?) Say Cheese IN SUCH  BAD MOODS  ALL THE TIME??? I love the selection of cheeses, wines, gourmet mustards, sauces...well, you get the idea. But man, I just can't do it. Brie and tomato sandwich shouldn't come with a side of attitude!!! I wish someone would open another cheese shop in the area so these guys wouldn't have such a monopoly...please, someone do it!
author: summer r.

description: The only place in the city where you can get a Parma de Porcettio for your extermly picky East Coast boyfriend without looking silly.  They'll also help you if you're trying to wow your Queer Masterpieces class with an amazing fondue.  They're always willing to help you find what you're looking for or turn you on to something you'd never pick on your own.
author: Kris J.

description:
Great cheese shop, nice to have in the neighborhood.    

My husband and i pop in here pretty frequently to buy their cheeses.  They have excellent sandwiches too.   My main complaint about this place is that the guys behind the counter making these delicious sandwiches never wash their hands after handling money, credit cards,(any transactions at the register).  They go from making sandwiches to working at the register, then back to making sandwiches.  Finally, the last time i was in, i had to ask the guy to wash his hands before making my sandwich.  He did!
author: Mark S.

description: I love this place.  They have THE best sandwiches- the Brie and tomato is so simple but SO good- and they are all really reasonably priced.  Only drawback is that there's nowhere to sit in the store to eat.  They also have a great selection of cheeses, olives, nuts, etc.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Very helpful staff and knowledgeable about what they sell. BEST SANDWICHES EVER!
author: Lisa M.

description: Incredible sandwiches -fresh ingredients, quality breads - made with good intention.  You can taste the passion for food these guys have.  Get them talking about food and you may be in there for a while.  Entertaining, knowledgeable, friendly and honest.  That's what I'm talking about.  And so what if they sass ya - sass 'em right back.  It's called style.
author: Michelina M.

description:
Service, selection, sandwiches, grilled vegetable... AMAZING.
We had them cater our party and they did a beautiful, fantastic job. Helped me pick out a great menu and they exceeded my expectations. This shop on the outside looks little but they totally deliver. Everything was delicious!
author: Jimara D.

description: I hate cheese and I love this place.  What more is there to be said?  Coppa on ciabbatta for the win!
author: Jeff R.

description:
Yeah. Say Cheese.
Pretty freakin' cool.

Excellent sandwiches, sometimes slightly dry, but unparalleled ingredients / freshness, especially for the price.

The dark guy is "bitter bob," and he's a genius. Yes, he's like the soup Nazi in that he suffers no fools. Keys to dealing with him......

1) Know what you want. 

One of his main reasons for being pissed is that you should probably know what you want after standing in line for 5 minutes. If you have questions, look him in the eye and smile but do not flinch or he'll write you off as a spineless pussy.

2) Don't waste his time with pleasantries or stupid questions.

The only possible way to get his respect is to ask relevant questions about cheese or wine that demonstrate your knowledge. In other words, he is a professor, not an elementary school teacher.

Sample stupid question: "Would I like this cheese?"

The answer Bob should / wants to give:
"How the f___ should I know??"

We are lucky to have acerbic dudes like him around to keep it real among a sea of Frisco-y ponytailed love-vibe sugarcoaters / it's NOT all good / deal with it / thanks to those dark-souled individuals like Bob and those tightly-run ships like Say Cheese that would not exist 
if there were, indeed, no worries.
author: jimmychanga c.

description: The sandwiches here are a step above. The prociutto here is something in and of itself to behold. And I personally haven't had the 'Sandwich Nazi' experience. Maybe it's my own grizzled European look or just the fact that I'm quick to order, I don't know. But I've never had any trouble from anyone here, and I'm always dazzled by the exceptional wine and cheese selection, albeit small. I'd certainly go broke if these kinds of sammies were in my neighborhood.
author: Michael E.

description: I have actually seen larger, more spectacular cheese selections but this is a very good selection with high overall quality.  The deli case is a work of art.  I love the bowl of carefully displayed, very fresh looking sardines near the olives, marinated peppers and other items.  I was not blown away by the meat selection.  I should have purchased that pound of corn/summer squash ravioli, because it probably won't be there next time and I don't know what we're having for dinner.
author: Kevin S.

description:
wow, what more is there to say beyond ...WOW! the cheeze selection looks like the beer menu at Tornado x 4 (in cheese terms of course).

Come in with open-cheesy mind, and you'll leave happy, and a lot fatter too. I went in hoping to get a tasty sammidge and some cheese, and walked out with a ferry building foodie-class knowledge/love for the various variations or roquefort....mmmm, tasty, tasty blue mold...

Friendly and knowledgeable service, tasty cheese, french booze (wine), and of course....roqeufort. uggg.....need.....to...work...out
author: Tim V.

description: Not sure what to get and you're having company over? Go to Say Cheese and let them know about the occassion- not only will they pair you with great cheeses, but you can taste them before you buy...always a bonus when learning something new!
author: Beth M.

description: their sandwiches are preferred to be made a certain way which I totally respect.  this ain't no corner liquor store sandwich joint.  Also they hide special salami's and cheese's only for people they like. so regulars always get the scoop.  eat the sandwiches the way they recommend it because you probably don't know any better.  I"ve spent many a good dollar here.  The simplistic and delicious sandwiches, the soft stinky pungent cheeses, mouth watering sides have all been delicious.  Just another reason I love living in/near Cole.
author: Diana L.

description: Personal, professional service from people who REALLY care about cheese. They remember your name and what you bought last month. All the ingredients - in the sandwiches, in the selection of highly edited pantry items - are top notch.  Quality really matters here - meaning, it's hard to wrong, whether you are buying cheese, olive oil, crackers or wine.  Sure, it's expensive.  But you don't have to do much for dinner when the quality of the individual ingredients is so high.  I love this place; it is such a pleasure to have it in the 'hood. (And yes, there is a one old guy behind the counter who is a grump.  But man, does he know cheese. If you can get him started on cheese, he turns voluble and really interesting. And the rest of them are really sweet.)
author: Mary B.

description:
I love this place.  The people there are awesome.  

If anyone gets attitude there, they probably deserve it.  

They know their stuff when it comes to cheese, and they have some of the best sandwiches around.
author: Steve H.

description: Great neighborhood cheese shop with a friendly and knowledgeable staff, which, for some reason, is rare at cheese shops in this city.  They also have a small but very good wine selection.
author: Tyler N.

description: The best cheese/sandwich shop in the city.  The sandwiches are to die for, and I've never once experienced the poor customer service some of these other folks have commented on.  All the guys are always super friendly.  It's usually one of my first stops back home after a business trip.  A great welcome home meal!
author: Irene W.

description: These guys know their cheese. From buffalo-milk mozzarella to fresh goat, the chalk board lists it, and the shop-keep will explain its uses or give samples. Prices are comparable to premium cheese in a supermarket and the quality is better. Also has a good deli for made-to-order sandwiches, fresh sliced deli meats, and sides.
author: Rick C.

description: Great cheese assortment and great staff. I come here about three times a week....and eat way too much cheese!!
author: Kathleen E.

description: Oh my god.  IF you want to find the perfect place to clog your arteries, and stop your heart,  say cheese. Please. good for elegnat picnics..
author: Kathleen G.

description:
i agree with everyone, both the lovers and the haters...
the selection is lovely, they have a section of good wines under $10 and they provide a service that we really can't get anywhere closer than, say, the Castro.

but geez, there can be some serious attitude.
there is one person in particular who is like the cheese Nazi-
if you don't order quickly and precisely, he will say "NO CHEESE FOR YOU."
well, really, he'll just go and help someone else, making you feel like a bumbling idiot.

sometimes we have to earn our cheese.
author: Melody O.

description:
perfect post-work pit-stop for fun snacking. or, a productive place to work up inspiration for a picnic. 

whenever my girlfriend and me walk home from work, we stop by this uber-convenient cole valley store.

i think every neighborhood should be home to a say cheese. 

it's so small but full of heart. and though the guys who work there may exude a somewhat intimidating air of gruffness, they're actually warm and very helpful. 

i usually stop in to pick up spanish chorizo (they're one of the few places that carry this particular kind), but usually can't resist the seduction of the cheese counter, so i end up picking up a tasty, smelly cheese that one of the guys recommend. 

i'm not a wine drinker either, but damn, when i'm there, i start getting in the mood. got the sausage, the cheese, why not pick up some crackers, date bread, and wine while i'm at it?

ALSO, say cheese carries framani salumi. yay.
author: jennifer y.

description: Yum. The cheese expertise is daunting, but they will help you get what you are looking for if you can describe what you like. The GF and I nearly always end up with a creamy wedge of d'affinois and a seeded baguette.  On a sunny day we like to grab reasonably priced Cab or Pinot and head to the park on my little Vespa. After sittng by the Dahlia garden and indulging ourselves, we begin to wish public fornication wasn't so terribly faux pas.
author: Dylan M.

description:
Say Cheese can be expensive, especially if you purchase their prepared food such as pasta sauces, sausages, condiments, and other stuff like that, although that is to be expected in a small specialty store.
