The sandwiches, however, are reasonably priced and if they have not run out of the bread you like, can be very good. I come here pretty regularly and have never had a terrible experience with the food, although I must say that twice when I bought the raw italian sausage (to cook later at home) I wound up questioning how fresh it was. There is no expiration date and it definitely tasted funny both times (but it's really good normally). If they are not diligent about throwing out food past its prime and the "funny tasting" sausage tasted bad because it was old, then I think that is really unethical. The problem is, I'm sure they'd never admit it if I asked whether or not the sausage was old. I know they are a small place and products may not move quickly, but selling expired/old sausages would be really messed up. I am suspicious....

My main complaint, however, is that sometimes certain employees can be really unfriendly. I know some yelpers have said that expecting someone to be nice is being too "sensitive," but when you work in customer service, it is your job to pull the stick out of your ass and at least fake being nice. It is not unreasonable to be offended when the person helping you is rude. MULTIPLE times I have cut my order short because I felt as though they were treating me like I was some nuisance wasting their time. The guy with the ponytail will talk on the phone for 10 minutes while you just stand there, waiting to be helped. OOHH, that's right, I forgot, you have so many important things to be doing running this cheese shop and all! Take your time, I'll just stand here!

I think when you are working at a gourmet deli, the vibe should be relaxed, ALL people should feel free to ask to try things or ask for suggestions, and your customers shouldn't be consistently and in large numbers complaining about how unfriendly you are. If you want to muse over what cheese would go best with what wine, etc., this may not be the best place for you because on average they won't be helpful and you will feel rushed. They will look at you like you are an idiot, choose one cheese, and pressure you to buy their selection. 

Oh, and allow me to be specific if I am going to say they are unfriendly. There are two older men with beards; the taller skinnier one is not very socially adept and can come off as rude, although he is more talkative than most of the employees and feels like he has a lot of knowledge to share with you (condescending and offensive sometimes, useful other times). The guy with the ponytail is almost always unfriendly. He gets the award in my mind for the most unpleasant employee to have help you (if he ever actually acknowledges you before someone else does). I just don't get it...
author: Amanda C.

description: Though it's selection is no where near that of cowgirl, rainbow, or whole foods, it's still a great spot...and not just for cheese, but for wine, sandwiches, pate, and the likes.  The service is friendly, and the cookies tempting you by the register are quite tasty as well.  Every hood should have a spot like this.
author: Sarah D.

description: They make a great sandwich and will sell you cheeses that you are guaranteed to love. Asked the clerk ( a young guy - not the fisherman-looking old dude) for a good goat cheese, and he selected one that he described as "retardedly good." How can you not appreciate that?
author: Beth T.

description: One problem I have found with SF is that for all the great restaurants it lacks the great neighborhood deli's I remember of my childhood.  This is one of those places.  Great selection of cheeses and meets.  Fabulos sandwiches and not to shabby of a wine selection.  The counter staff is alway friendly and rarely pretentous.  It is worth the trip to cole valley alone for this gem of deli.
author: brian m.

description: It's all you want: a wide selection of quality cheese. The man behind the counter seemed wistful for a bygone era when cheese played a greater role in the lives of San Franciscans, and I think that probably explains the "bitterness" mentioned by some. I love the place and just wish it was open a little bit later.
author: Justin V.

description: Great cheese shop with amazing selection of cheese and the unique character of an independent neighborhood store.
author: 'toph G.

description:
This is not only the best cheese shop but also the best sandwich place in the city.
Good 'hood feeling.
Anyone who thinks that its not good because of A#$holes working there clearly doesn't understand the place. I am happy that some don't like the place because this keeps the line wait to a minimum and keeps the riffraff out. When the staff rolls their eyes at customers it is ALWAYS justified! 
These guys give a damn and always deliver great service and give great wine and cheese recommendations. NO BS.
For those who don't like it,  you can always go to Safeway, where they always smile and remember your name when you buy your Velveeta.
author: Sparky S.

description: Great selection, great sandwiches and reasonably priced.  BUT, if I see that the older man with the beard (owner?) is working, I don't even bother.  He's so surly and unpleasant.  All the other guys who work there are great but Ol' Grumpy bums me out.
author: Suzanne L.

description: I love coming here for sandwiches on a warm day before walking to GG Park for picnics. They make delicious sandwiches that are simple and filled with fresh meats. Any of the Italian meats are great and their roast chicken is delicious. They also carry a very wide variety of cheese and the staff are more enthusiastic about cheese than many of the other cheese specialty shops in the area. They also boast a great selection of olives and really affordable wine, as well as some European specialty treats.
author: Alicia J.

description:
great selection of sandwiches on a variety of breads, including many italian breads.  they have a lot of dif veggie sandwiches as well, which is a plus.  the sandwich maker i had was a bit gruff and kinda scoffed at me for asking for a bag for my sandwich.  sorry, i was carrying a lot of things and wanted to consolidate, so shoot me.  otherwise, the sandwich was good.

if i ate cheese, i would come back for that as there are a ton of cheeses, and the chalkboard makes selecting a breeze, as they are all categorized by country and type.
author: Helen T.

description: I haven't been here in years.  I remember it being service-oriented with a fine selection of cheese.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Another longover due review. I used to live in Cole Valley and loved visiting the local businesses in my 'hood. I went to this cheese shop one time and was treated so rudely that I would never go back. They had a stack of boxes of wine inside the store. I saw that it was a wine I was familiar with and had enjoyed many times so I wanted to check on the price. I looked at the bottles and found no price tags so I asked the man behind the counter how much the wine was. I don't remember more than one other customer being in the shop but perhaps I was disturbing the man in some way because he responded, "Can't you read the price on the bottle". I was so taken aback that it took me a moment to respond, "There isn't a price tag on the bottle." He may have told me the price after that but I don't remember because I was so angry that I stormed out. How dare you treat a potential customer in that way! I wouldn't touch this place with a ten foot pole. If you want lovely selection with nice staff, go to the 24th Street Cheese Company in Noe Valley. They are simply the best.
author: melanie k.

description: This place was great! We had excellent service from everyone especially Richard. He was very knowledgeable and friendly. We walked out with a lot of cheese and goodies for $20. The best deal we've found by far!!! I love this place! Customer service was great. Not sure why people are saying it's bad.
author: Corrie C.

description: Not too long after I moved into the neighborhood, I wandered into Say Cheese and whoa!  Seriously, there is so much cheese packed into this tiny store, it can be a little overwhelming.  Not to worry, the folks here can help you out if you love cheese but are a little cheese-impaired (like me).  And their sandwiches are top quality too--they slice the meat for each order.  Plus they'e different than the normal deli sandwiches you usually find--I love their cajun turkey.
author: Leslie R.

description: This place knows cheese but they have so much more. You can find some of the best olives, olive oils, italian wines and meats as well. Try their sandwiches if you get a chance (I love the cajun turkey). However, the staff can seem annoyed you are there and have an expectation that you should know more about what they sell than they do. I like the sandwiches enough to get past their lackluster attitudes though!
author: Ryan M.

description: Friends took us here to pick up sandwiches for our day out. Although the service is extremely slow -- there was no one else in line and it took maybe 15+ minutes to make four, cold sandwiches -- it is absolutely worth the wait. The sandwiches are so good, and the portions are huge. I had the fresh mozzarella, basil, tomatoes and prosciutto. It was amazing! Quite possibly the best sandwich I've had in San Fran!
author: Courtney D.

description: I was lucky enough to live right around the corner from this amazing shop for 8 months and I'm sure my waistline reflected my proximity. Between my roommates and me, we probably went through 3 pounds of cheese each week. If you go often enough and know how to ask intelligent questions, the staff will quickly become your best friends. I would go in for anything from one of their awesome sandwiches (Jambon, Gruyere and french butter!) to cheese and wine for a nice dinner party. I could have eaten there every single day.
author: Becky G.

description: This place is SO overpriced and the staff isn't so friendly.  You can find the same cheese (and many more) for much less at Cheese & Things on Polk Street, people.
author: marie m.

description: I really want to tell u.... GO TO THIS PLACE. It's just some cheese store with some some italian guys running it, but Damn there sandwiches are ridiculously good. I forget what it's called but there is a sandwich with perscuto,tomato,basil,olive oil and FRESH mozzarella, soooooooooo good.
author: Jason B.

description: I want to eat everything inside this store.  I sometimes consider skipping work for their sandwiches.
author: Dan H.

description: Amazing assortment of cheeses, meats, olives, jarred/canned gourmet items, etc.  I go there for lunch sometimes and get their roasted chicken specialty sandwich (jack cheese, sun dried tomatoes, basil, and pesto mayo) on dutch crunch.  SO GOOD!
author: Jenny S.

description: Small little store, with a somewhat friendly staff.  They have a great selection of cheeses, but I go there most of the time for their sandwiches.  Highly recommending the Mozzarella, tomato, basil on bread of choice (I usually get the panini) for $6.  I've had other sandwiches there, and they were not as good.
author: Max T.

description: This place is so cute. Makes me want to only shop in specialty stores!
author: All About Town ..

description: Great Sandwichs! Great cheese. Some times the older gentlemen in there tries to tell you what you like, but if you get any of the younger people they usually suggest a few different things and let you sample. Its a small store and very crowded when busy.
author: angela s.

description: The food itself is lovely, but the proprietors have a thing or two to learn about customer service -- and honesty.  Sometimes they are neutral -- not friendly or rude, and sometimes they are rude.  And when they're rude, they're VERY rude -- saying things like "Are you going to make a decision or not?" when the store wasn't even busy.   And my neighbor had a similar negative experience -- she went once and never went back.  But the worst thing is the creative accounting.  I live in the neighborhood and used to go there every week. When you buy multiple items, they write the items on a paper bag, or on the back of your wrapped sandwich, for example.  But the last 3 times I went, I discovered that the amount they ran through on my credit card was much higher (by as little as $2, and by as much as $5) than the amount that you added up from all the items, even taking into account an 8.5% sales tax.  And of course they never give you an itemized cash register receipt, just the credit card slip. Having that happen once, I could see as an honest mistake.  Having that happen three times in a row... that makes me wonder how much they've bilked from me over the years....
author: Kris A.

description:
I've come to the conclusion that this shop best meets the needs of cheese connoisseur only.  I like cheese, but I guess my tastes are a bit pedestrian - more than brick cheddar, but I'm not sure I appreciate the foreign cheeses the staff usually recommend to me.

The last time I shopped here I had a list of three California cheeses I wanted to serve at a party.  They only had one of the three I requested and couldn't recommend any other California cheeses in place of the other two.  One of their recommendations, epoisses, was a stinky cheese with only a gummy flavor.  I can't imagine how this could be anyone's favorite.

It probably didn't help that I was wearing sweats and a day's worth of stubble when I was there.  I'd been working on my party all day and hadn't had a chance to clean up.  I might have received a bit more consideration if I'd looked a bit more Pacific Heights and a bit less Haight Street.
author: Nolan M.

description: Great cheese with employees who love cheese and are willing to talk about it.  They store their cheeses at the proper temperature and always cut to order.  I would like to see more American producers represented but Bob claims they are overpriced clones of the European originals.  I think this might just barely edge out 24th Street Cheese as the best cheese shop in SF.  Show some interest and an open mind and they will not lead you astray.  Couldn't they have come up with a better name though?
author: Brian O.

description: I love say cheese.  They have the greatest stinky cheese and the bitter guy is cool.
author: melissa o.

description: I really like this place. I always try to patronize my local Cole Valley establishment, and it's pretty easy here. It's a tiny little shop that sells wine, cheese, and everything else related. Their sandwiches are amazing. I saw in a previous review that it took them 15 minutes to make their sandwiches, but mine was ready in less than 5 minutes. I didn't get the chance to buy any cheese, but their selection looked extensive, to say the least. The store itself is really small, so waiting can be a bit of a pain, especially if there are more than 3 or 4 other customers. My bf and I came here to get a sandwich, some chips and a bottle of wine to drink in the park and the guy at the register knew what was up and gave us some cups to take with us. I will definitely be going back, this is a great find.
author: Em G.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!! I don't know anything about Cheese and every time I go in there, they are so nice to me and very patient.  They really go out of their way to help me find something I like, no matter how many different types of cheese I have to try.  I don't have a big budget either and I still get wonderful cheese!!!
author: N K.

description:
the assortment is great!
The staff is awful..its such a miss. They argue/grumble with each other, talk under their breath, it is a real bummer cause the shop is truely worthy.
I have been in retail, i'm not an enititled customer...they are paid to deal with the public..is pleasant so hard?
author: christopher w.

description: I just moved into the neighborhood and so far, I'm a fan. I haven't had any of the issues with bad service that other people describe, though the employees haven't struck me as going out of their way to be friendly either. But still, to live within walking distance of this sort of selection of cheeses? Wonderful, when you're a novice who wants to learn more about wine and cheese pairings. I expect to be back a heck of a lot.
author: B L.

description: what a great place, a foodie's delight. a great range of cheeses from around the world and prices which don't drain your wallet. the olive oils and balsamic vinegar are some of the tastiest. i'll go back over and over again. not a big place but a big satisfaction...try it yourself
author: sebastian r.

description: stopped in after lunch at thawesome place.  seriously friendly and knowledgeable guy behind the counter.  awesome cheese selection (first time i had ever tried the Chimay Rind).
author: Amelia C.

description: i find the upper haight restaurant scene to be lacking in almost every department. i think say cheese is THE lunch spot. tasty sandwiches, knowledgeable cheese mongers, tasty homemade snacks, and a good selection of drinks all add to the charm of this little gem. great for a voyage into the park.
author: lucy m.

description: If I lived across from Say Cheese I'd be the fattest kid on the block. I love cheese and crackers and this place has all kinds of both. I've only been here twice (in the same day) but got a chance to try a ricotta made from buffalo milk that a friend picked out, and a prosciutto and mozarella sandwich. Both were really really good. Also, I haven't tried any of them yet, but they have a good amount of wine, oils, vinegars, and all that other good stuff that goes with cheese. Next time you're stopping at Cole and Carl on the N, you should definitely stop by.
author: Jane C.

description: Great cheese selection, good if a little overpriced European wines, excellent sandwiches.  That said, I dread being waited on by two of the guys who have been there for years.  They are frequently rude and curt and make you feel like you're bothering them with you patronage.  Lately I've been going for the pressed sandwiches at LAVA JAVA on Stanyan.  The sandwiches are less expensive and the service is great!
author: Carl R.

description: Yeah, so, I couldn't hold out.  See, there just aren't that many options for a quick dinner around here, between Cole Valley and the Haight.  Sure, you can sit down, or order something to got, but as far as quick service around here, your only options are pizza, a burrito, Mcdonalds, or a sandwich from Say Cheese.  And the thing is, their sandwiches are gooood!  So, I figured, today, when I got off the N, before I walked home, that I'd just look in the window, and see what I saw, and you know what I noticed?  Neither of those guess who I'd had that confrontation with, that I wrote about before, neither of them were working today.  So you know what I did?  I went in and bought one of their salami sandwiches.  Want to know why?  They use the dry Molinari salami, have gruyere as an option, keep sliced rye on hand, douse it all in oil and vinegar, add a bit of decent roughage, and season with S&P without even asking; all for $7.  Really, what more could one ask for?  And you know what?  It was awesome!  Want to know what I've decided?  They can treat me like shit if they want, I can accept that, as long as the sandwiches taste this good.
author: todd f.

description: Very impressive selection of cheese. Staff was incredibly well informed and very knowledgeable on all of their products. Cheese in general is a bit expensive, but if ever I have some "mad money" this is the shop I hit first.
author: Kelli T.

description: I'm so shocked that people have had terrible customer experiences at Say Cheese!  I'm in there all the time, and I always rely on the friendly staff for my cheese selection.  I've been introduced to some really great cheeses that way--I just give them a rough idea of what I need (and sometimes a budget), and they pick out something AMAZING and give me recommendations (an 8 year aged cheddar with apple slices? YES!)  They couldn't be friendlier!
author: A M.

description:
After reading the reviews that the guys who work here are mean, I thought they would laugh me out of the store if I went in and asked for a sandwich without bread. What is that even called anyway? 'Cause it's not a sandwich anymore....Yes, I'm all for carbs, and I'm not doing the trendy anti-wheat diet, rather the straight up, doctor confirmed celiac disease. I may not have the intestinal fortitude to digest wheat, but I do to face possible mockery for a chance to enjoy a "sandwich" like the rest.
 Score! I thought  that at best, they would throw something together for me, but it turned out so much better. 
Paul was so caring, and accommodating!
 While asking me why I couldn't have bread, he was interrupted by the phone and said "don't go anywhere, I want to figure this out" Then there were other people waiting and I said they could go ahead but he was determined. Star! After my explanation, he said "well you've got to eat too" and he offered to put all of the ingredients of whatever sandwich I wanted together. He even adjusted the typical sandwich price for the lack of bread, asking me if I thought that was fair!!!Two stars! He asked me if I was new and welcomed me to the hood. He let me pay by credit card.
I haven't been treated this well at places that have totally positive staff reviews! 
Oh, and as for the "sandwich", it'd be pretty funny if it was just so-so after such a great experience. But it so lives up- another star for the amazing taste. All the ingredients were crazy fresh! I took a bite walking home, and it was gone before I got to my door. Holding a sandwich in one hand and eating it while walking may not be so hard with bread to hold it together, but without the bread? Another star for the accommodating  architecture.  
 See you tomorrow Say Cheese!
Update-
Say Cheese continues to please. I really, really, try to not be a freak about things like money to food handling, but try as I might....I am indeed a freak
When I asked about his hands, Sean, in addition to be totally cute, said "they're clean, but I'll wash them again for you" and proceeded to do so  with lots of suds and a smile.
LOVE YOU GUYS!
author: E K.

description: this place and i have over 15 years of history. for the longest time i was known as the pastrami guy because i think i ordered the same sandwich about 98% of the time over those 15 years. but then they stopped carrying pastrami. even with that i still go back. not so much for the cheese but for the sandwiches. the service is pretty good. one of the guys has been working there since i've been going. i wouldnt describe him as friendly in the typical sense as he probably comes across as gruff to some. but to me he has always been cool and i know he takes pride in his work, even if it is just a sandwich. this place is in my rotation of regular sandwich spots, highly recommended. oh and i heard they sell great cheese too.
author: A G.

description: Say Cheese is definitely one of those places that makes me thankful to live in a true San Francisco 'neighborhood'.  It's small, offers an amazing array of imported cheeses, salami, olives, oils and even a decent (but minute) selection of delicious wines to wash it all down.  By and large, most of the people working here are extremely friendly and helpful except for one older guy (don't know his name) who is continually rude and unprofessional.  He seems extremely fond of himself and what he has to say, is very finicky with how he treats his customers and is generally prone to spewing all forms of irrelevancy to just about anyone who will listen (i.e. 'tolerate') him.  I do wish they'd dump this guy - but I fear he could actually be one of the owners.  Alas.  Sometimes I simply do a quick 'drive-by' before stepping inside to avoid him entirely ... I'm curious if anyone else has had the same experience with him?
author: Bruno Y.

description: Bottom line: Excellent and delicious cheeses, but if you go in there and receive help from anyone but the guy someone described as "the fisherman" (and he is AWESOME), then you can expect snarkiness, sarcasm, rudeness bordering on complete and utter a-holeness. In particular, I'm talking about the dark-haired kid with the goatee who is perhaps one of the biggest d*cks I've ever come into contact with, ever. I was excited to go in, choose some cheese and wine for the day, and I greeted him with smiles and pleasantness. Didn't matter. Not at all. He rolled his eyes at my selections, and when I tried one of his suggestions and didn't like it, he was just utterly, bafflingly rude. It was unbelievable. It is sad because I won't be going back there, and up until today I loved that place. He's just a total jackass. If you see him there, turn right around and leave, unless you enjoy being treated like that. No cheese is worth that much rudeness, not even the cheese from this place. And it makes me feel sorry for the Fisherman because he obviously loves cheese and enjoys working there, while this other kid seems hateful, mean and totally disrespectful. How can you be so hostile when you work in a CHEESE SHOP?! I hope he gets fired. Soon. The world would be more balanced that way.
author: Katherine S.
